creator: jason@redfish.net
text:
Symlink appears to use suboptimal logic to determine whether the link that the developer wants to make is already there.

If overwrite is on, the correct thing happens, but it deletes and re-creates the link each time.

If overwrite is off, then the task just calls "ln -s resource link", which, if the link already exists and is a directory, makes a link to the resource as *another* symbolic link inside the directory. 

IMHO, the symlink task should not carry with it the side-effects of the "ln" command, but should do what its documentation says. I suggest that if overwrite is off, the task should check to see whether the link itself exists (with File.exists() and Files.isSymbolicLink()), and if it does exist, then do nothing.

creator: jaikiran@apache.org
text: I have submitted a PR https://github.com/apache/ant/pull/49 containing a fix for this issue.
